title: Ticket #7696: GPU discovery should report stable GPU ids
description:
We have discovered that when a GPU goes bad on a machine with multiple GPUs, Docker will refuse to use any of the GPUs until that GPU is taken offline (via nvidia-smi drain). Once a GPU is taken offline, however, it disappears from GPU enumeration, and the GPUs after it move down 1 index.

Since GPU ids are currently GPU indices, this essentially shuffles the GPUs behind the Startd's back causing who knows what problems.

We need to change condor_gpu_discovery so that it reports stable identifiers for the GPUs. This can be done by using the GPU uuid instead of the GPU index. Also NVIDIA allows the uuid prefix to be used, so long as it is not ambiguous. So we will use either the first 8 characters of the uuid, or the whole uuid. DetectedGPUs then becomes 

    DetectedGPUs="GPU-5498e439, GPU-bc8c14c7, GPU-112d9b26, GPU-d298c6e0"

instead of 

    DetectedGPUs="CUDA0, CUDA1, CUDA2, CUDA3"

And GPU specific attributes become 

    GPU_5498e439DevicePciBusId="0000:3E:00.0"
    GPU_5498e439DeviceUuid="5498e439-bec3-fa72-ed65-a45d5f53e1b5"
    GPU_bc8c14c7DevicePciBusId="0000:60:00.0"
    GPU_bc8c14c7DeviceUuid="bc8c14c7-ad51-371f-de8e-36ae559b39ed"

instead of 

    CUDA0DevicePciBusId="0000:3E:00.0"
    CUDA0DeviceUuid="5498e439-bec3-fa72-ed65-a45d5f53e1b5"
    CUDA1DevicePciBusId="0000:60:00.0"
    CUDA1DeviceUuid="bc8c14c7-ad51-371f-de8e-36ae559b39ed"
